name: Annette Mills
comments: She was born Edith Mabel Mills in Wandsworth, London. She had intended to be a concert pianist and organist, before she became a dancer, subsequently finding fame as an international exhibition dancer. However, fate struck her a cruel blow when she was forced to retire from professional dancing after breaking a leg. That career over, she turned her hand to songwriting and penned the two popular tunes "Boomps-a-Daisy" and "Home, Sweet Home Again", amongst many others. Some time later, Mills returned to the work of cabaret and revues, and it was while she was on her way to entertain the troops during the Second World War that she was involved in a horrific car accident.  She is best remembered for being the partner of the puppet "Muffin", in the successful BBC Television children's series Muffin the Mule between 1946 and 1955. She wrote the songs and the music, while puppeteer Ann Hogarth wrote the scripts.

name: Veikko Laiho
comments: Accordion player, who founded a trio with his two brothers Altti U. Laiho (1939-2017) and Pentti K. Laiho (1944- ). An opportunity to perform outside Finland opened in 1967 and the Laiho Trio made their first North American tour in the years 1968 and 1969. Under the name Oliver, Laiho made a radio broadcast of Elvis's old songs and asked Chrisse Johansson for translation of the lyrics, which was the start of her career as a lyricist in 1969.

name: Trio de Ouro
comments: Singing group founded by Herivelto Martins, who earlier was in a duo called "Preto e Branco" (Black and White) with Francisco Sena, replaced by Nilo Chagas in 1935. When Martins married the singer Dalva de Oliveira in 1936, she was added to the duo and the "Trio de Ouro" (Golden Trio) was founded. The trio performed and recorded together until 1948. In 1949 Dalva separated from Herivelto. The couple's separation and divorce was prolonged, bitter and public. Their dispute and mutual accusations were featured not only in press coverage, but in the lyrics of songs recorded by each of them. When she left Herivelto one part of the Brazilian public viewed Dalva as a fallen woman and another part, as a rebel and hero.

Her brother Tom was also in vaudeville, revues and movie shorts as an eccentric dancer and comedian.

name: Conny Stuart

Schmidt and Harry Bannink including their first "Heerlijk duurt het langst" from 1965. The show was an incredible success and Schmidt and Bannink wrote four more musicals for her.

name: Max Blokzijl

Although based outside the Netherlands, Blokzijl, who had become a convinced Nazi, joined the National Socialist Movement in the Netherlands (NSB) in 1935. He returned to his homeland following the 1940 German invasion and became the propaganda chief for the new NSB puppet regime. Blokzijl became the first Dutch collaborator to be executed in Scheveningen.

name: Jean-Louis Pisuisse

On November 26, 1927 he and his wife were murderd on the Rembrandtplein in Amsterdam by his wife's ex-lover, who committed suiced after the deed.

name: Laurence Hope
comments: English poet who wrote under the pseudonym Laurence Hope. In 1901 she published "Garden of Kama", which was published a year later in America under the title "India's Love Lyrics". The life and poetry of Adela Nicolson have inspired a wide range of adaptations, beginning with British composer Amy Woodforde-Finden's musical settings of four of the lyrics from "The Garden of Kama" to music. The most popular of these was "Kashmiri Song". After the songs proved a critical success, Woodforde-Finden added four settings of lyrics from Nicolson's 1903 book "Stars of the Desert". African American composer Harry Burleigh published "Five Songs of Laurence Hope" in 1915.

name: Mammoth Gavioli Fair Organ
comments: The largest of eight 112 key instruments supplied to Britain in 1908-09 by the Paris firm, Gavioli, and probably the largest fair organ ever built this one was supplied in 1909 to front Sidney White's Electric Coliseum Bioscope And Variety Show, South Wales.  It was reduced to a 98-Key in the Welsh Dragon Scenic Railway. The organ travelled in fairs until 1930, when it found a permanent home in the Cosy Corner Amusement Park, Barry Island, Wales.  The ride was closed in 1939 due to war and never re-opened and was dismantled in 1954.  Since then, it was restored by George Parmley of Chester Le Street, County Durham and was fully functional from 1956 to 1964.

name: Stoll Picture Theatre Orchestra
comments: Orchestra of the Stoll Theatre on 22 Kingsway, London. This theatre opened as the London Opera House, a project of American impressario Oscar Hammerstein to have his own theatre in London which would be a rival to the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. It opened on 13th November 1911. The building was huge, the area covered 24,500 square feet of ground and cost over 200,000 pounds to build. It took up an entire block along the newly constructed Kingsway. Hammerstein was forced to close the London Opera House on 13th July 1912. In 1916 Oswald Stoll took control and on 31st April 1917 he converted the building into a full time cinema, known as the Stoll Picture Theatre.

name: Ernest Bucalossi

Until 1928 he was musical director at a variety of London theatres. Ernest is today best known for his "Grasshopper's Dance", and the rest of his compositions have slipped into obscurity.

name: The Palm Court Theatre Orchestra

It was formed in 1978 by Anthony Godwin, at that time principal bass clarinettist with the Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra, when he inherited a complete and rare library of vintage music from his father whose extensive family had all been musicians during the early years of the 20th century.

name: Jacques Canetti
comments: Music executive and a talent agent born in a Sephardic Jewish family in Ruse, Bulgaria. He joined Polydor in 1931, where he persuaded Marlene Dietrich to record her first album of French songs. After World War II he became artistic director at Polydor and in 1947 he opened the "Théâtre des Trois Baudets" in Paris. This venue hosted a number of famous French performers, including Georges Brassens, Jacques Brel, Guy Béart, Serge Gainsbourg, Francis Lemarque, Félix Leclerc and Juliette Greco. In 1963 Canetti left Philips and founded his own record label and production company. He was the brother of the Nobel Prize-winning author Elias Canetti (1905-1994).

name: Charles Graham
comments: Songwriter and bass singer born in Boston, England. In 1880, seventeen-year-old Graham moved to Halifax, Nova Scotia, and later settled in New York City. He wrote several enormously popular songs but made very little money from them. In particular, he sold "The Picture That Is Turned to the Wall" to Witmark Publishers for 15 dollars. The song became the first big hit for this company which, 70 years later, published early songs of Bob Dylan. In July 1899 Graham died penniless in Bellvue Hospital, New York, leaving a widow and five young children absolutely destitute.

He was an apprentice in a boat building business before becoming a professional entertainer in 1888, making his first appearances in pantomimes and minstrel shows. By 1895 he had become a leading music hall entertainer, appearing at the Middlesex Music Hall in London and developing an act that was considered somewhat risqué for the time. Described as a "low comedian", his popular songs (written by others) included "A Little Bit Off the Top", "The Cock of the North", and "When I Get Some Money

name: Nick Cave
comments: Cave was the singer in The Boys Next Door, a students band which later became The Birthday Party. After the latter's disbanding, Cave started The Bad Seeds with three Birthday Party members, soon joined by Blixa Bargeld, and Mick Harvey as a band 'anchor man'. The act enjoyed an increasing cult status and had their international break-through with "Where the Wild Roses Grow", a vocal duet by Cave and Kylie Minogue. Besides his band work, Cave has been an avid soundtrack composer, partly with Harvey and Bargeld and partly with Warren Ellis. He contributes to many musical projects in various artist constellations and is also known as an author of books and a movie scripts co-writer.
